column6: Claiming To Be An Ex-Cop
column7: Who Promises To Transfer Our Crores And A Banker Who Leads Us To All These Big Fish:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Again
column4: we have another banker
column5: no less a crook. The banker in question is R. Manohar
column6: Assistant General Manager
column7: Indian Bank
column8: South Delhi. In his zeal to net such client with deep pockets as our to-be-found-nowhere minister who could put on his table Rs. 25 crore of unaccounted cash
column9: Manohar guides Cobrapost investigative journalist
column10: Syed Masroor Hasan
column12: an orthopedic surgeon from Tirupati who wants our minister to invest his crores of black money in his real estate project.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">There are many twists and turns to the tale.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">We are invited to Hyderabad where we meet Vasu
column4: a hawala operator
column5: who claims to be a former Andhra cop. He would help us deliver Rs. 25 crore to Dr. Prasad at Tirupati for his project through is racket. Our next port of call is S. Sake
column6: who is Minister of Primary Education with the Andhra Pradesh government
column7: with nine other departments under his charge
column8: which shows the power he wields. Sake stands guarantor for the safety of our black money investment in Dr. Prasad’s real estate project. This helps us uncover a nexus between the banker and the hawala kingpin who are running their racket without any fear of law
column9: with active patronage of our political masters.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">We don’t know how many bankers are doubling up as henchmen of hawala racketeers.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><u><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">The Nexus Between the Banks and the Insurance Companies:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Another fact that comes to the fore is a nexus between the banks and the insurance companies. If the banks don’t have their own insurance companies
column4: they have joint-ventures with private insurers. Yes Bank
column5: for instance
column6: has a tie-up with Bajaj Allianz
column7: which would question an investor only when the investment crosses Rs. 1 crore
column8: as we came to know from a Yes Bank official. And such investments can be done in cash. Whenever we went about proposing to bankers
column9: public or private
column10: that we wanted to invest our black money in insurance
column11: they immediately called the managers of the their insurance associates to our presence or sought their advice on phone
column12: making it amply clear that banks and insurance companies are hand in glove.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">What the Law of the Land has to Say on Money Laundering?

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">The videos
column4: through Cobrapost’s undercover investigation in Operation Red Spider Part II
column5: clearly show the gross violation of rules and regulations
column6: framed under various laws of the land
column7: namely
column8: the Prevention of Money Laundering Act of 2000
column9: the Income Tax Act and the Indian Penal Code
column10: among others.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Sections 118
column4: 119 and 120 of the Indian Penal Code which clearly establish an offence in both scenarios: Where an offence has been committed and where an offence has not been committed. If we test the Cobrapost findings on these provisions
column5: although “no transaction” took place
column6: their willingness to conduct transaction establishes their design of committing an offence and hence their culpability beyond doubt. The IPC also establishes concealing the design to commit as an offence and as such holds it punishable to a term defined therein.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Here is what Section 120 of The Indian Penal Code
column4: 1860 says:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">CONCEALING DESIGN TO COMMIT OFFENCE PUNISHABLE WITH IMPRISONMENT

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Whoever
column4: intending to facilitate or knowing it to be likely that he will thereby facilitate the commission of an offence punishable with imprisonment
column5: voluntarily conceals
column6: by any act or illegal omission
column7: the existence of a design to commit such offence
column8: or makes any representation which he knows to be false respecting such design

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">IF OFFENCE BE COMMITTED- IF OFFENCE BE NOT COMMITTED

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Shall
column4: if the offence be committed
column5: be punished with imprisonment of the description provided for the offence
column6: for a term which may extend to one- fourth
column7: and
column8: if the offence be not committed
column9: to one- eight
column10: of the longest term of such imprisonment
column11: or with such fine as is provided for the offence
column12: or with both.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">As to the sweeping statement of the RBI Deputy Governor that “Allegations do not mean flouting norms
column4: ” we can only hold the various provisions of Prevention of Money Laundering Act of 2002 as mirror to what he claims to be “transactional issues and have nothing to do with money laundering”. Section 3 as defined in the Act 2002 emphasizes:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; margin-bottom: 0.0001pt; text-align: justify;""><b><i><u><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Whosoever directly or indirectly attempts to indulge or knowingly assists or knowingly is a party or is actually involved in any process or activity connected with the proceeds of crime and projecting it as untainted property shall be guilty of offence of money laundering.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: times new roman
column3: serif;"">

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><u><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Are the RBI or the Finance Minister unaware of the above clause of the PMLA? Is attempting to launder money for a politician who has generated cash through corrupt practices
column4: not a proceed of crime?

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: times new roman
column3: serif;"">

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><u><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Cobrapost''s Method to Unearth this Scam:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">The method was the same: Taking an alias
column4: Cobrapost Associate Editor Syed Masroor Hasan
column5: posing as a relative of an imagined politician
column6: made cold calls on dozens and dozens of branches of these banks and insurance companies. And the proposition was the same: A politician of stature wants to convert huge sums of black money into white. Could the officials help?

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">It didn’t take much effort to pull the lid off the murky world of money laundering as the officials of these companies rolled out a red carpet for our Masroor Hasan who visited dozens and dozens of branches across the length and breadth of the country
column4: including many major cities and state capitals
column5: across all five zones.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><u><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Nowhere was Hasan disappointed. Nowhere was he turned away. Almost every banker and insurer he met with was willing to help launder huge unaccounted cash the fictitious politician Masroor Hasan was representing.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><u><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">How They Help Launder Your Black Money?

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Here
column4: we give a summary of the modus operandi that all bankers and insurers suggested to help convert black money into white
column5: leaving nothing to imagination:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Accept huge amounts of unaccounted cash to invest it in insurance products
column4: and sometimes in gold as well.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Open an account to route the cash into various investment schemes of the bank or insurance arms.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Do it even without the mandatory PAN card or adhering to KYC norms.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Arrange forged PAN cards to facilitate investment of huge unaccounted cash.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Split the money into tranches
column4: below the reporting threshold
column5: to get it into the banking system without being detected.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Use accounts of other customers to channelize the black money into the system for a fee.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Get demand drafts made for the client either from their own banks or from other banks to facilitate investment without it showing up in the client’s account.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Keep the identity of the investor secret.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Open multiple accounts to invest the unaccounted cash directly in cash-investment schemes.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Buy as many policies as you can to accommodate the huge unaccounted cash.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Open an account in some extension branch a couple of months before the investment matures
column4: credit the returns in that account and close it as soon as you withdraw all your money. The point: Extension branches are seldom audited.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Advise the investor to remain invested for a certain number of years
column4: say
column5: 7 years
column6: to keep the taxman at bay.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Allot as many lockers as the client needs for safekeeping the illegitimate cash.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Personally come to the residence of the client to take the black money deal forward and collect the cash
column4: even bring along a counting machine.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Use provisions like Form 61 to show the unaccounted cash as income from agriculture
column4: making the investment of black money and returns thereof unquestionable.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Promise to help transfer overseas huge sums of black money with the help of such operatives as hawala kingpins.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">Promise to convert all your unaccounted cash into white through other conduits
column4: someone like builders who need cash for their own operations
column5: or someone who owns a company.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1in;"">Ø
column3: sans-serif;"">

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1.25in;"">o
column3: sans-serif;"">One interesting fact that emerged in our investigations is that some bankers and insurers suggested us to buy insurance products in whomsoever names we wanted and assign those instruments in our name
column4: that is
column5: our imagined minister
column6: so that at the time of maturity we could harvest the returns. This is akin to holding a benami property where the owner of the property is not the one in whose name the property has been bought.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1.25in;"">o
column3: sans-serif;"">Another unique idea proffered by some bankers was open multiple accounts in the names of any individuals
column4: not necessarily drawn from family
column5: and become joint account holders
column6: to monitor the accounts and keep all the details and cheque books with ourselves. This could serve our purpose better
column7: and we could enjoy peace
column8: after all our ill-gotten money is slipped into regular banking system and comes back to us as clean.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 1.25in;"">o
column3: sans-serif;"">Insurance has emerged
column4: whether with private or public sector insurers
column5: as the most favorite tool to launder money
column6: undetected.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Needless to say what all these suggestions mean: a clear intent on the part of these officials to commit a crime as defined under various Indian laws
column4: such as the Income Tax Act
column5: the Indian Penal Code
column6: FEMA and the Prevention of Money Laundering Act.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">We are sure the RBI top brass will again go about town touting the expose as something of a non-issue since no transaction of cash has taken place
column4: as both D. Subbarao and his deputy K.C. Chakrabarty did when we exposed the three major private banks
column5: namely
column6: HDFC Bank
column7: ICICI Bank and Axis Bank on March 14
column9: giving a clean chit to these banks. And we know they would claim that the banking system is “safe and secure” debunking our findings with their typical nonchalant bureaucratese. But they have been proved wrong
column10: with the RBI’s own audit report indicting these banks now out
column11: and forcing the banking regulator to follow it with punitive action against the erring banks.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">The optimism aired by the central bank’s top honchos that Indian banking system is “safe and secure” is nothing but a naïve interpretation of the reality of the day: Our economy is overwhelmingly grey than it is white.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><i><u><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Let us quote a nugget of wisdom from a gentleman banker who believes
column4: to put in a lighter vein
column5: our economy is strong because of black money and all the talk to check it is just talk: “Dekho ji jo chalta hai Hindustan mein ... chalta toh wohi rahega ... baaki upar jo bhi hai ...wo  hota rahega ... sub baatein hoti rahengi (You see what is going on in India would go on ... what happens in the upper echelons will go on ... there will be all sort of talk).” The same banker tells why this phenomenon would go unabated: “Kyonki jo control karne wale hain unhin ke paise lage huye hain ... hai ki nahin (Because those very people who are supposed to control it have invested their own money ... isn’t it).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><i><u><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">A sad commentary on our economy
column4: and who control it
column5: but nonetheless a cold truth.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><u><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">The Impact of Cobrapost Expose:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">In between the first expose of March 14 and this expose
column4: certain developments have taken place. For instance
column5: all the banks have been asked to strictly adhere to KYC norms
column6: and even older account holders’ antecedents are being verified without exception. The banks alleged to have been involved in money laundering have punished their staff members
column7: more than 50 in numbers
column8: with suspension
column9: although they are just a cog in this wheel. In yet another development
column10: miss-selling by insurance companies to the tune of Rs. 1.5 trillion
column12: making the gullible investors as much poor
column14: and there is an effort on the part of certain quarters to use this to deflect attention of the nation from the real issue of money laundering and the dangers inherent to it which are now being openly discussed in the print media
column15: and other public fora such as ASSOCHAM
column17: although the electronic media silence over this issue is conspicuous and deafening.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><u><span style=""font-size: 14pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Can the System Be Cleaned Of The Malaise?

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">Although the RBI has announced action
column4: both at the systemic level and at the individual bank level
column5: one can only hope they are not cosmetic
column6: and the latest expose would spur both the RBI and the IRDA to address the malaise
column7: for all times to come.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">However
column4: looking at the RBI’s rather suspicious
column5: Protector-instead-of-Regulator conduct
column6: it looks highly unlikely that any worthwhile cleansing of the system will happen.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">It is high time our financial institutions are overhauled
column4: so are the monitoring systems of both the RBI and the IRDA
column5: to clean up the system
column6: and put in place checks and balances. While the RBI should take a rethink on its licensing policy
column7: as many private insurers and NBFC players are making a beeline to seek regular banking licenses from the central bank
column8: the IRDA should forbid all insurers to entertain cash transactions. The IRDA should also revisit the wealth management portfolios of all the insurers
column9: to help identify the faults inherent to such lucrative business opportunity. Only then can one hope of redeeming our pledge to international community India has given when it became a signatory to FATF (Financial Action Task Force on Money Laundering).

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">More than that what is at stake is national security
column4: and it is anybody’s guess what havoc it would wreck on India’s economy and social fabric if forces inimical to Indian state take advantage of such all-pervasive permissiveness in our financial institutions.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">However
column4: given the virtual cover-up post the first expose
column5: we are not very hopeful that a full-scale clean-up of this sort will take place
column6: ever. And there is reason behind this skepticism of ours born out of government’s own actions. For instance
column7: the Ministry of Finance has wrapped up the Directorate of Criminal Investigation (DCI) that was set up to check the flight of black money out of the country and bring the culprits to book
column8: under the mandate of the Parliament. It was this agency which was on hot pursuit of those industrialists and politicians who have parked their black money with the Geneva branch of HSBC Bank and whose name were made public by the French government. One can draw an unmistakable inference from this episode that far from being serious on a serious crime like money laundering
column9: the government is working at cross purpose
column10: thus leaving our financial borders as porous as our geographical borders are.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; font-family: arial
column3: sans-serif;"">At the end of this release you will find some selected excerpts of confessions of officials of these institutions exposed.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;""><b><i><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px; font-family: times new roman
column3: serif;"">HERE ARE SOME EXCERPTS OF CONFESSIONS BY SOME BANKERS AND INSURERS OF THEIR PAST INVOLVEMENT IN MONEY LAUNDERING

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">M. Sharma
column3: Branch Head
column4: Birla Sunlife
column5: Jaipur
column6: Rajasthan

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Accepting the proposed huge cash investment:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Aap mujhe cash mein de dijiyega … main uska DD banwa loonga (You give me cash … I will get a DD for it).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how should we withdraw the returns after the investment matures:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Jab bhi bhavishya mein aap is paise ki maturity lene waale hon toh ek fresh account khulwaiyega … jab withdraw karna ho ek fresh account khulwayiega … bank account … us bank account ko do ya teen mahine se operate karne lagiyega … bank account mein paisa credit hoga … paisa aane ka jariya ek hi hai … wo to number ek ka ban ke hi aayega (Whenever in future you withdraw the money at maturity
column3: open a fresh account … operate it for two or three months ... the money would be credited in to that account … this is the only way the money can be received … that will cone only after it is converted into Number 1 [white]).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">S. Sharma
column3: Branch Manager
column4: Birla Sunlife
column5: Associate Partner
column6: Moradabad
column7: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Assuring us our unaccounted cash would become white:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “White ho jayega … bus white ho jayega wo fir (Will become white … then that will become white).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On what he would with our cash:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Aap chahe cheque se dijiye chahe DD banwa lijjiye cash … hum DD banwa denge uska (Either you give us cheque or you get a DD for that [cash] … we will get the DD made for you).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">He would keep his regional manager in the loop to help use invest maximum unaccounted cash: Sharma:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“RM ko le aoonga … usse kya hai na ki saara kaam aur bhi 25–30 lakh jitna bhi maximum hota hai … bahut log karte hain yahan par (I will bring the RM [to the meeting] … that will help us to invest another Rs. 25–30 lakh to the extent maximum [amount of cash] … a lot of people do such investments here [with us]).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">A. K. Gupta
column3: Chief Manager
column4: Bank of Baroda
column5: Parliament Street
column6: New Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Telling us not to worry as what we have proposed it like peanuts:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Main keh raha hoon tension hi nahin … ye sub kaam toh chote hain … saare mantriyon ke khaate hain (I am telling you there is no tension … all these tasks are like tidbits for me… we have accounts of all the minister).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">D.K. Prasad
column3: Manager
column4: Trade Finance
column5: South Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">It is apparent what Prasad is saying:
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;""> “Toh black ko white kyon nahin kar lete (Why don’t you make black white).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;""><i><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">On how he would get us some company owner who would take in all our black money and would issue us a cheque
column3: of course for a fee:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Wo company ke through jo hoga wo aapko cheque dega … jo itna genuine kaam hoga wo aapko pata hai … wo bhi is tareeke se apna … bade bade CA jo returns wagaireh hain wo usmein adjust karenge (That will be done through a company … that fellow will give you a cheque … that will be a genuine job … you know it … they use this method … big CAs who prepare returns etc. will adjust in their books).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">M. Goel
column3: Senoir Manager
column4: Canara Bank
column5: South Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how we should go about slipping our unaccounted money into the banking system:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">“<b><i>Pehle account khol lenge … main aapko form de doonga … slowly slowly jaise hota hai
column3: I mean ek baar lump sum mein nahin kara payenge
column4: zyada hi hoga toh Sir se boliye locker denge … for a time being you will keep …ghar mein rakhna risky hota hai … you will keep in the locker (First open an account … I will give you the form … it will be done like slowly
column5: slowly … I mean we will not be able to do it in a lump sum … if it is required tell Sir we will give you a locker … for a time being you will keep … it is risky to keep the money at home … you will keep in the locker).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Counting his clients who put in their ill-gotten money through him:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Policewale hain kyon ki wo bhi … doh teen policewale hain … ya doh teen builder ke hain (There are some policemen because they too … there are two-three policemen … there are two-three builders).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">S. S. Kumar
column3: Divisional Manager
column4: Canara Bank
column5: Agra
column6: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;""><i><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">Bring all your crores and put in a savings account
column3: your money is conevered into white:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Definitely take care … savings [account] mein rakha toh kuch nahin hoga … kuch nahin hoga (If you keep the money in savings account
column3: then nothing will happen) …  It will not be reflected anywhere … even income tax mein nahin jayega… but aapko interest kum milega (It will not be reported to the Income Tax department but you will get lower interest).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">C. M. Duggal
column3: Regional Head
column4: Federal Bank; R. N. Munjal
column5: Relationship Manager
column6: IDBI–Federal
column7: Moradabad
column8: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">R. N. Munjal
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On converting our unaccounted cash into DD and then invest it:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Direct cash de DD banwa dete ... koi dikkat nahin ... wo sub humara headache hai ... aapka kuch bhi nahin (Give direct cash
column3: will convert it into DD ... there is no problem ... all of that is our headache
column4: not yours).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how peope bring in all their black money and ask him to invest:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Meerut ... Dehradun mein bhi kaafi hain ... paise log laate hain kehte hain ... number do ka paisa hai ... ye karwao (In Meerut ... many in Dehradun as well ... people bring Number two [black] money ... ask us to get it done [convert the money into white]).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Unki baat hai kareeb ek saal pehle ki ... unka daala near about ek crore rupaye ... aath–nau lakh rupaye barh gaya hoga ... aise case to bahut hain Sir (His case is about a year old ... I put in near about Rs. 1 crore for him ... now it has grown by about Rs. 8–9 lakh ... there are many such cases).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Teen kare the unhone ... do mein 20-20 lakh
column3: ek mein unhone kara tha ... 35 lakh ke aas paas (He had bought three policies ... two for Rs. 20 lakh each ... one around Rs. 35 lakh).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">G. Agarwal
column3: Manager
column4: IDBI Bank
column5: South Delhi
column6: New Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">G. Agarwal
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how our black money would be put into the banking system without the mandatory PAN:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Account khol lenge ... without PAN card ... usmein 49
column7: 000 karke aap daily cash daalte jao ... daily (We will open an account without PAN card ... daily put Rs. 49
column8: 000 cash in it ... daily).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On foreign remittance:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Gift hi dikhayenge ... ya toh koi parh raha hai ... educational purpose se ja raha hai ... England mein property khareed rahe hain (Will show it as a gift ... or somebody is studying ... [the money] is being sent for educational purposes ... you are buying property in England).”
column3: serif;"">  “Thoda thoda hi karna hai
column4: serif;""> (Will have to do it in small chunks).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">V. Joshi
column3: Assistant Manager
column4: IDBI Bank
column5: Central Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how our unaccounted cash would be routed through multiple accounts:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">“<b><i>Uske liye ye karo ki aap ke naam pe ya kisi ke bhi naam pe ... jitne bhi log kar rahe hain
column3: unke account khol ke us paise ko route karao pehle (For that
column4: first you open accounts in your name or in the name of anyone ... all other persons who are doing it ... route the money [through them]).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Understanding well our purpose of money laundering:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Main samajh gaya ... aap ko black ko white mein convert karna hai (I have understood ... you want to convert your black money into white).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how he would route our black money through an account:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;""> “<b><i>Jab bhi aapka payment ka time ayega
column3: pehle aap ke black money ko mein route karoonga account mein
column4: account se white karne ka route karoonga ... isiliye co-ordination chahiye (When the time comes for you to make payment
column5: first I will route your black money to the account
column6: then I will route that money [into investments] through account for making it white ... that is why I need [somebody for] co-ordination).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how he has helped bigwigs to launder their money in the past:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Main jab Lucknow mein tha toh main Gomti Nagar ki branch mein hi tha ... wahan pe jitney bhi syndicates the ... investments karwate the ... unke saath kaafi dealing hoti rahti thi ... aur wahan pe aapne dekha hi hoga ... ya toh wahan IAS officers ke ghar hain ... sub constructors ke ghar hain ... bureaucrats hai ... wahan black money ka flow kaafi zyada rehta tha (When I was in Lucknow
column3: I was in the Gomti Nagar branch ... all the syndicates there ... would make investment ... I used to see through a lot of dealings there ... and as you must have seen ... IAS officers have their residences there ... [almost] all constructors have their homes there .... bureaucrats live there .... there is a lot of flow of black money there).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; line-height: 19px;"">K. Prasad
column3: Senior Manager
column4: Indian Overseas Bank
column5: Moradabad; A. Agarwal
column6: Manager
column7: Life Insurance Corporation
column8: Moradabad
column9: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; line-height: 19px;"">A. Agarwal
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; line-height: 19px;"">On how investing in LIC helps make you money white:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify; line-height: 19px;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 24px;"">“<b><i>Actually
column3: LIC mein jaake number ek ka to ban hi jayega … doosri baat aapko return bhi mil raha hai FD se jyada (Actually
column4: the money will become Number one [white] once it [money] gets into LIC … second
column5: you will also get more returns than fixed deposits).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; line-height: 19px;"">There are many big clients who Agarwal helps invest there millions with LIC;

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify; line-height: 19px;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 24px;""> “<b><i>Ek ek party chota mota amount nahin deti … pachees pachees
column3: tees tees
column4: paintees paintees lakh rupaye deti hai … araam se ho jaata hai (Each party give us anything between Rs. 20 lakh and Rs. 35 lakh … we do it easily).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">D. Luther
column3: Chairman Club Member; T. Chopra
column4: Development Officer; R. Nagpal
column5: Assistant Branch Manager
column6: LIC of India
column7: North-West Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">T. Chopra
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Nahin nahin … abhi peeche pachees lakh kisi aur ke karaye hain (No
column3: no … only recently I have got Rs. 25 lakh invested for another fellow).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-top: 12pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">D. Luther

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin: 12pt 0in 10pt 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Aisa kuch nahin aata … yahan se koi aisa nahin jaata … yahan toh croron croron aata hai (Nothing of that sort [income tax notice] comes … nothing is sent from here … crores of rupees are slipped into it [LIC]).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-top: 12pt; text-align: justify;"">R. Nagpal
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin: 12pt 0in 10pt 0.5in; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">“<b><i>Haan
column3: bees lakh rupaye abhi cash jama karaye hain … raseed bhi hai inke paas aap dekh lo (Yes
column4: [he has] got Rs. 20 lakh deposited a short while ago … if you want he can show you the receipt).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin: 12pt 0in 10pt 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Aap 25 crore bhi lagaoge toh bhi theek rahega yahan pe … government company hai (If you invest Rs. 25 core
column3: even then it will be alright here … this is a government company after all).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-top: 12pt; text-align: justify;"">Kapoor

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin: 12pt 0in 10pt 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Har ek aadmi ke paas ek aisa account bhi hota hai jisko wo declare nahin karata… zarrori nahin hai ki aapke paas agar chaar account hain toh chaaron ke chaaron aapne income tax mein declare kar rakhe hain … ek aisa bhi account hota hai jahan se aapko thodi bahut upar ki amdani hai usko bhi save kart hain(Every person has an account which he has not declared in his income tax [returns] … it is not necessary that if you have four accounts you declare them all … there is always an account in which you save your extra income).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin: 12pt 0in 10pt 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">M. Khanna
column3: Assistant Branch Manager
column4: LIC of India; K. Joshi
column5: LIC Agent
column6: Gurgaon
column7: Haryana

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">K. Joshi

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Same day loan ho jayega Sir. Black ko white karne ka isse acha tareeka nahin (It will be sanctioned the same day Sir. No method is better than this to make your black money white).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“PAN card banwa doonga alag se … PAN card banwa doonga alag se (I will get you made a separate PAN card … I will get you a separate PAN card).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">“Usse pahle Pankaj Sharma ne lagaya tha baees laakh lagaya tha (Before that Pankaj Sharma had invested Rs. 22 lakh).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">M. Khanna

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“It’s ok … loan lena toh bahut badhiya hai … loan se white ho jayega (It is ok … availing of a loan is all the better … loan will make it white).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Main officially inko bol nahin sakti … main samajh rahi hoon … PAN card toh karwao inse  … kyomki mera bhi  system nahin leta …. aap kya de rahe ahin kya nahin (I can’t tell him officially … I understand it … get the PAN card done from him … because my system won’t take it … whatever you are giving).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Main aapko naam disclose nahin karoongi … dekhiye wo toh humara confidential hota hai … agar koi aapka poochega hum usse bhi nahin batayenge … koi problem nahin hai (I will not disclose you the names … look that is confidential for us … if someone asks us we will never tell him … there is no problem).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">R.K. Singhal
column3: Assistant General Manager
column4: Noida
column5: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Humare yahan se koi nahin jayegi … aapki kitab kisi ke haath lag gayi to alag baat hai … humare yahan se koi report nahin jaati  … bahut saare kahte hain is terah ke (No report will go from us … if somebody else lays his hands on your book
column3: then it is a different case … we don’t send any report … we have many accounts like this). ”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">S.K. Setia
column3: Chief Manager
column4: PNB
column5: South Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Toh main us angle se hi karata hoon jo bhi product hai (Then
column3: I will do it with that angle whatever the product is).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">S. Mishra
column3: Chief Manager
column4: PNB
column5: South Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how all transactions are kept confidential:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Ye sub toh bahut confidential cheezein hoti hain na … ab matlab agar aapko nahin jaanta hai koi toh wo aapko … matlab entertain koi nahin karega yahan …. kisi bhi soorat mein (All these things are very confidential … I mean if nobody knows you here then they would … I mean nobody will entertain you here in any case).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Jo bhi dealing hai … agar humein kisi ko batana hoga ki aap isse se ye jaankari le lijiye tab hum aapko wahi number denge utne hi kaam ke liye ki aap ye cheez unse pooch sakte ho agar by chance main bahar hoon toh (Whatever the dealing … if I have to tell you that you can seek that particular information from somebody … only then will I give you his number for that specific purpose telling you can ask him about this thing … if by chance I am out of town).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">K. Madhumathi
column3: Territory Manager; Chandrashekhar
column4: Sales Manager
column5: Reliance Life
column6: Hyderabad
column7: Andhra Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">Madhumati
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Doing big cash transactions are routine:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Yesterday evening only I picked up one 50 lakh cash … aapke jaisa hi … he was not a politician but a businessman … very big businessman … toh unko kya hai ki his name should not come out (Yesterday evening only I picked up Rs 50 lakh … same as yours … he was not a politician but a businessman … a very big businessman … all he wanted is that his name should not come out).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how customer’s names are kept a secret:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Because we block the names … because customer ka naam bahar nahi aana chahiye (Because the names of the customer should not be revealed)… because many of the customers are having black  money where they want to make it as a white … name aane se ek baar Income Tax ko pata chal jayega na toh un logon ki life kharab kar denge (if their names come to the knowledge of the Income Tax officials they will make their lives miserable)
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">An investment proposal of Rs. 1 crore is like peanuts compared to what they do:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Croron ka karte hain bhai sahib … ek crore to bahut chota amount hai … hum log  yahan 50 crore 80 crore ka karte hain … and Reliance mein Ambani ke group mein to itne saare karte hain poori yeh Rajasthani log hai na … Rajasthani log zyada karte hain … Marwari (We do it for crores [of rupees] … Rs. 1 crore is a very small amount … we here do it for around Rs. 50–80 crores … and there are many customers who invest with Reliance of Ambani group … these Rajasthani Marwari people do the most).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">M. Raghu
column3: Territory Manager
column4: Reliance Life Insurance
column5: Hyderabad
column6: Andhra Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how we can get forge PAN card to invest with his company:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Without PAN card karna hai?...  Doosra PAN card nikaliye (You want to do it without PAN card? Get another PAN card).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Ek baar pakka karne ke baad kya karte hain naya PAN card nikaal dete hai … with a spelling mistake kariye ... kuch na kuch karke PAN card nikaal dete hai … because of these people lots of default log ho gaya hai … bahut log do–teen PAN card lekar rakha hai … wo PAN card rakhte hai … PAN card rakhe toh … wo PAN card ke naam pe IT ko jaata hoga … pata nahi (Once we decide [on the investment]
column3: what we do is we make a new PAN card … with a spelling mistake on it … anyhow we would manage a new PAN card … because of this there are many defaulters … many people have two–three  PAN cards … they keep the [original] PAN … which means … they file returns to the IT [Department] … don’t know).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how safe it is to invest with Reliance:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Safety safety … bahut saara paisa aisa hai (It is safe … a lot of money is [invested this way] there).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">R. Shankar S
column3: Senior Territory Manager
column4: Reliance Life Insurance
column5: Bangalore

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how big chunks of unaccounted cash are routine with Reliance:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Aaj savare ji saath lakh cash collect kar ke laaya tha … yehi same thing (Today morning itself
column3: I collected 60 lakh cash … for the same thing).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Our unaccounted cash would be converted into DDs for investment in Reliance Indurance:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Nahin humein DD banana hai … that we will make (No
column3: we have to make the DD … that we will make).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">V. Yadav
column3: Senior Territory Manager
column4: Reliance Life Insurance
column5: Gurgaon
column6: Haryana

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On investing in gold:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“One-time payment hai … aage aapki immediate pension start ho jayegi… paise ko aap… white ka paisa ayega … paisa aapka monthly mode milega … usko kahin gold kharido… main aapko best bataoon … yahan se jo paisa mila aapko… usse har mahine gold kharido (This is a one-time payment … pension will start immediate[ly] … the money will be white ... you will get it in monthly mode … you buy gold with it … I tell you the best thing … purchase gold every month with the money you get back from us).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On facilitating our black money investment:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Main aapko cheque doonga apna ... aapko trust hai toh main daalonga kis tarah se … main DD banwaonga … tukdo mein … dus-dus lakh ka DD banwaonga (I will give you a personal cheque … if you trust me then I will make DD … put it in … in parts … I will get DDs made of Rs. 10 lakh each).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“DD main aapka different different account se banwa doonga … uski payment aapko karni padegi DD ki … paise toh lagte hain na DD ke (I will get the DDs made from different accounts … but you will have to pay for that ... after all you have to pay for the DDs).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Even a fake address would be added to our account:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Address jahan aap rehte ho doosra address lagwa denge … wo address bhi nahin rahega … banda dhoondega bhi to kisko … mobile number aapka rahega bus …  aapse koi pooche toh haan main hoon … aapki koi verification nahin hogi … kuch nahin hoga (We will give an address other than where your stay … that address will not be there … who they will look for? Only your mobile number will be there … if somebody asks you say yes I am … there will be no verification … nothing that sort).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">A. K. Agarwal
column3: Chief Manager
column4: State Bank of India
column5: Noida
column6: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how nothing would change in India:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Dekho ji jo chalta hai Hindustan mein ... chalta toh wohi rahega ... baaki upar jo bhi hai ...wo  hota rahega ... sub baatein hoti rahengi ... sub baatein hoti rahengi na (You see what is going on in India would go on ... what happens in the upper echelons will go on ... there will be all sort of talk ... there will be all sort of talk).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">It is black money which makes our economy stronger:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Haan ... usme dekho kitne America ke bank jo ki itne bade ... analyst ye sab mante the ... unki haalat bhi kharab ho gayi na ... toh yahan nahi hui ... aisa thode hai ki yahan par unke paas koi special cheese chal rahi thi … khali ye tha ki yahan pe number do ki economy badi strong chalti hai (Yes ... see what happened in America ... all the big banks
column3: which analysts too held as infallible ... crumbled ... but it didn’t happen here ... it is not that here they [the banks] are working on something special ... the only thing here is that we have a Number 2 [grey] economy which is running very strong).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Money can be laundered with help from other sources:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Aise toh log mil jaate hain ... aise toh ho jaata hai ...  kyonki unko khud ko No. 2 chahiye ... jo log builder ... ke kaam mein lage rehte hain ... wo convert kar lete hain (You can get such people ... this can be done .... because they too want no. 2 [money] ... people like builders ... like engaged in those kinds of profession ...  they convert it).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">A. K. Jain
column3: Relationship Manager (Personal Banking)
column4: State Bank of India
column5: Aligarh
column6: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Sabse best hai… bank mein kar denge kuch ismein kar denge … tukdo mein kar denge … dheeme dheeme kar denge … ek saath nahin karenge (This is the best … some we will do in bank [savings instruments] … some we will do in it … we will do it in parts … we will do it slowly
column3: we will not do it in one go).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Locker se nikaal ke usmein daalte rahenge … laocker se nikaal ke yahan rakhenge wahan daal … usmein (We will keep on putting in there after taking it out from the locker … taking it out from the locker we will keep it here [in the account] ... put in there … in that).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">J. Kaur
column3: Chief Manager
column4: State Bank of India
column5: Panchkula
column6: Haryana

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Fir main bata doon mutual fund best rahega … na toh wahan pe koi hai batanewala ki sources of fund kahan se aya … na hi ismein wo cheez hai … wo kar sakte hain … (Then
column3: I shall tell you mutual fund will be the best … there is no requirement for you to reveal the source of fund … from where it has come … there is nothing like that … you can do it).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Matlab dus lakh se neeche transaction rakh lo … aath aath nau nau karte ho aap cash jama karate ho toh ye jo hai na monitor hoti hain transactions … aisa na ho fir aapko kal fir wo transactions … (I mean you keep the transaction below Rs. 10 lakh … Rs. 8 lakh
column3: Rs. 9 lakh each … if you deposit cash then such transaction are monitored … then it may happen that tomorrow those transactions can be monitored …).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Meri baat suniye aapko wo deke hi jayega … aisi koi baat nahin hai … lekin wo hai ki aapki safety bhi toh dekhiye na … aapne do number ki entry ek mein kar li(Listen to me
column3: it will give some returns anyway … there is nothing to worry … but you should also see your safety … you will have converted the No. 2 entry into No. 1).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">P. Kumar
column3: Branch Manager
column4: State Bank of India
column5: Noida
column6: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Haan abhi filhaal utna daal dijiye fir usmein kuch jo hai na mutual fund ka … uspe karwa denge … account mein dheere dheere daalne se na tab nahin poochenge wo (Yes
column3: put in only that much right now … then we will put some in mutual fund … if you put in gradually then they will not ask).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">V. Mahajan
column3: Assistant General Manager
column4: State Bank of India
column5: Gurgaon
column6: Haryana

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Ussmein jama karayein account mein … account se wo kar lijiyega (Deposit [cash] in that account … do that [invest] through account).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;""><b><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">Y. Rana
column3: Sales manager; K. Singh
column4: Branch Manager
column5: Tata AIG
column6: Noida
column7: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">Y. Rana
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Long term ke liye … actually inhein khali cash se karna hai … aur black se thoda  white karna hai (Actually
column3: he wants to invest only in cash for long term … and wants to convert it to white).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">K. Singh

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Saara white ayega … pehle main ye check kar loon kitna paisa hum invest kar sakte hain (It will come all in white … [but] let me first check how much can we invest).”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Diya hai Sir pichle saal diya hai … pichle saal humne … isse jyada hi tha (We have done it last year … last year we … it was a bigger amount than what you have).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">A. Pal
column3: Financial Advisor/Senior Manager
column4: Yes Bank
column5: Gurgaon
column6: Haryana

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;""> “Politicians ko nahin diya lekin bahut bade bade logon ko diya hai (I haven’t sold it to politicians but I have given it to many big shots).

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Ab IRDA kya kehti hai … agar aapne koi paisa insurance mein lagaya hai … usko che saal baad agar aap nikaalte ho… toh aapse income tax department ye bhi nahin poochega ki paisa kahan se aaya … usmein koi tax liability nahin banti hai (Now
column3: what does IRDA say? If you have invested in insurance and if you withdraw it after 6 years … the Income Tax department is not supposed to ask you from where did the money come … then there is no tax liability).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“White karne ka sabse safest method hai aur sabse close method hai (This is the safest method to convert black into white and this is the closest method).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">A. Tripathi
column3: Banker; S. Arora
column4: Assistant Manager
column5: Yes Bank
column6: South Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-indent: 0.5in;"">S. Arora
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On our purpose to make our money white:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“Main ye aapse poochna chah raha tha ki aapko convert karna hai seedhi si baat hai … cash mein hi karna hai aaur teen bandon ke naam pe hi karna hai (I want to ask you that you want to convert [the money into white] … it is as simple as that … want to do it only in cash and in the names of three individuals)?”

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;""> “Dekhiye main aapki investment cash mein karwa doonga … main jo dikhaoonga ek cheez ye ho sakti hai … ki aap yahan pe account kholo… account kholo account mein aap cash jama kar do … cash jama karne ke baad uske baad main DD bana ke route kar doonga … jo maturity pe aapko paisa milega wo cheque ke through hi milega … ya account mein direct credit hoga … wo doosre …. jayega toh wo white ho jayega (See
column3: I will get your investment done in cash … what I will show
column4: for example
column5: is that you open an account here ... deposit cash here … after you deposit cash in the account ... I will make DD and will route it … whatever amount you get after maturity will be by cheque or will be directly credited into your account ... what will go will become white).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how we can show all our illegitimate cash as an agricultural income:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“Doosra main aapko ye bata raha hoon jo ki zyada beneficial hai … main ye karoonga aapka main dikha doonga agricultural income … agricultural income hai Chattarpur mein … main aapko ye baat bata doon ki Chattarpur mein main … jitna bhi  hai … jitne bhi aise transactions hoti hain … mostly agricultural income ka hi khata hai … main yehi karoonga ki ek Form 61 hota hai … Form 61 hota hi yehi hai ki meri ye income jo hai agricultural income hai… uspe likha hua hota hai … main wo Form 61 sign karaoonga … dus lakh rupaye aapse cash loonga aur dus lakh rupaye seedhe investment kar doonga (Second
column3: what I am suggesting you is much more beneficial … I will show it as an agricultural income … I have agricultural income from Chattarpur … all such transactions are shown as agricultural income in the accounts...  there is this Form 61
column4: which declares that this money is my agricultural income … it is written there on it ... I will get a Form 61 signed by you … then I will take Rs. 10 lakh cash from you and invest it).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">S. Maheshwari
column3: Senior Vice President; S. Singh
column4: Manager; K. Khatri
column5: Investment Head
column6: Yes

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">Bank
column3: Jaipur
column4: Rajasthan

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">S. Singh

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Ek kaam karte hain na … yahan par khata khulwa dete hain aapka … uske baad dheere dheere account mein paise jama karwate hain ... matlab isi account mein nahin sub jageh pe bhi … consolidate yahan par karte hain ... uske baad usko start kar denge (Let’s do one thing … I will open an account for you … after that gradually keep depositing money in it … I mean not only in this account but also in all other accounts … but will consolidate [the funds] here
column3: after that we will start).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">S. Maheshwari

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Account to aapka khul jayega … investment toh aap bologe toh aaj aur kal mein kar denge … wo toh DD banwa lenge hum kahin se bhi … uski koi tension nahin hai (We will open an account for you … if you say
column3: we will make the investment either today or tomorrow ... we will get the DD [for the cash] from somewhere else ... no tension about that).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">K. Khatri

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Sir wo to seventh year ... ek hum aur bata dete hain … agar aap ho jaata hai to first year ki money after seventh year white hogi … second year ka paisa after seventh year white hoga ... third year ka paisa after seventh year white hoga … as per income tax law (Sir that will happen in the seventh year … let me tell you one more thing … if investment is made then the money you give in the first year will turn into white after seventh year … the money you give for the second year will turn into white again after seventh year ... the money you give for the third year will become white after seventh year … as per income tax law).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;""> <b>“<i>Nahin
column3: nahin Sir humare paas aise bahut se accounts hain jisme bees–bees crore ki investments maine karayi hai (No sir … we have a number of accounts with us where I have got investments of Rs. 20 crore each).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Sir bahut hain … Sir bahut hain (Sir... there are many) but we can’t disclose … don’t worry… that’s why I am not disclosing … I can understand that.”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">S. Vats
column3: Manager
column4: Oriental Bank of Commerce
column5: South Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">When asked if the PAN card details are disclosed:
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-indent: 0.5in;"">“Nahin yahan se kuch nahin disclose hota (No
column3: nothing is disclosed from here).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">M. K. Pandey
column3: Assistant Manager
column4: Indian Overseas Bank
column5: Noida
column6: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how we should invest our unaccounted cash in different avenues:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“Dekhiye do–teen cheez ka investment usmein kijiye ... ek cheez mein mat kijiye ... Tax Saver kara lijiye ... aap ... gold coin mein investment kar sakte hain (Put your money in investments in two–three things ... don’t invest all in one ... invest in the Tax Saver ... you ... go for investment in gold coins).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">M. K. Pandey
column3: Assistant Manager
column4: Indian Overseas Bank
column5: Noida
column6: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how we should not put all our money in one basket:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“Dekhiye do–teen cheez ka investment usmein kijiye ... ek cheez mein mat kijiye ... Tax Saver kara lijiye ... aap ... gold coin mein investment kar sakte hain (Put your money in investments in two–three things ... don’t invest all in one ... invest in the Tax Saver ... you ... go for investment in gold coins).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">Swearing to secrecy:
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-indent: 0.5in;"">“Koi disclosed nahin hoga (Nothing will be disclosed).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">M. Gupta
column3: Senior Manager
column4: Federal Bank
column5: Ghaziabad
column6: Uttar Pradesh

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how he would get our black money made white with the help some other parties:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“Kuch humhari party hogi ... jo is tarah ka kaam karti hai ... paisa apse le lenge ... aur  aapke hi account mein transfer dikha denge cash ka (We have a party who do these things ... they will take your money and transfer the cash in your account).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On transferring abroad our crores of unaccounted cash:
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-indent: 0.5in;"">“Uske liye to hawala kar deta hoon (I can have a hawala [transaction] done for that).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-indent: 0.5in;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">P. D. Mathur
column3: Regional Head
column4: Trade Finance Operation; Y Kumar
column5: Branch Operation Manager
column6: Dhanlaxmi Bank
column7: Central Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">P. D. Mathur
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">Asking us to invest in RD:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Jitne bhi daaliye ... aap ... kitna hai (Whatever you want to put in ... how much do you have)?”
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">Rs. 60 lakh
column3: says our reporter. More
column4: about Rs. 5–7 crore
column5: is expected in March. We raise the stakes.

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in;"">Y. Kumar
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;""><i><span style=""font-size: 12pt; line-height: 18px;"">After the bankers refuse to entertain our proposition
column3: when we ask if we could do it through an account:

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;"">“Account ke through kar lo ... kuch bhi ... koi dikkat nahin (Do it through the account
column3: no problem).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On how we could slip our unaccounted cash into the regular banking system using a benami PAN:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “PAN card ki kahani yeh hai .... dekho PAN card kitno ke hain aur kiske hain ... apne nam se toh generally hote bhi nahin hain ... koi naam se agar man lo hoti hai toh unmein sub mein agar PAN hai toh ek baar PAN number ke saath aap deposit toh kitna bhi kar sakte ho ... toh koi problem nahin hoti ... aur deposit karne ke baad agar aap cheque se dete hain toh insurance mein kitna bhi laga sakte hain koi problem nahin ... yani ki ghuma firake ho jayega (The story of the PAN card is like this ... many people have PAN cards and in whose name they have ... generally they don’t have it in their names ... and once there is a PAN card with whatever name ... then you can deposit as much as you want ... and after the deposit if you give it by cheque then you can invest any amount in insurance ... by hook or by crook it is taken care of).”
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">On when asked if we could by 5 kg gold from the bank using an account:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “Account kholne ka kya zaroorat hai? Main baat kar loonga cash mein kaise karenge ye log (What is the need for opening the accounts? I will talk to them how it will be done in cash).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On transferring money overseas:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“Uska ilaz bhi bata denge ... kara denge ... bahut bari cheez hai nahin ... bahut choti cheez hai ... wo kya hai ki Euro mein convert ho kar ke chala jayega (I will tell you the remedy for that too ... it is not a big deal ...  it’s a small thing ... it will go after converting it into Euros).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">V. L. Mathur
column3: Chief Manager
column4: Dena Bank
column5: South Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how we should slip our ill-gotten into the banking system:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“<b><i>So March tak aap usmein jama kar sakte hain ... savings account mein ... tin logon ne apna account khol diya hai ... hum nau nau lakh sabse jama kara denge... sare nau nau lakh ... PAN number zaroor usmein note rahega ... lekin koi problem nahin aayegi ...information nahin jayegi ... ye March tak ke liye ... iske baad April ke baad mein
column3: financial year jo change ho gaya
column4: fir jama kar lenge ... koi bhi ek toh dus lakh se zyada ki single entry nahin honi chajiye (So till March you can deposit ... in the savings account ... [suppose] three of you have opened their accounts ... we will take deposits of Rs. 9 lakh each form each account holder ... Rs. 9.5 lakh in each account ... the PAN number will sure be noted on it ... but no information will go ... after April
column5: when the financial year changes
column6: we will yet again deposit ... there should be no single entry over Rs. 10 lakh).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how our money can be made white with someone else’s help.
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“Kisi ... aise aise log hain jisko cash de karke wo cheque de denge (There are people ... if you give them cash
column3: they will give you cheque [against it]).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-align: justify;"">R. Singh
column3: Branch Manager
column4: Development Credit Bank
column5: East Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">When asked if our money would turn white:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in; text-align: justify;""> “<b><i>Nahin
column3: TDS nahin hai… complete white ho jayega (No
column4: there is no TDS … it will become completely white).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how he would make our investment safe for us:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;""> “Yahan branch level pe kuch cheezein hoti hain jo hum manage kar sakte hain (There are certain things at the branch level that we can manage).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">R. Utreja
column3: Back-Up Branch Manager
column4: HDFC Bank
column5: Parliament Street
column6: New Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">Utreja seeks to meet the minister:
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-indent: 0.5in;"">“Aap meeting karwa sakte ho unse (Can you arrange a meeting with your minister).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how we should invest all our ill-gotten money safely:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;"">“Main aapko Sir main ek advise karti hoon … jo aap keh rahe ho na pachaas hai total… toh isko har saal dus dus kar do na … poora white ho jaye …har saal dus dus kar lo na seedha … usmein koi dikkat aapko bhi nahi aayegi … aur tax-free hoga … na paisa katega aur section ke neeche rebate bhi milegi aapko (I would like to advise you … what you are saying … it’s Rs. 50 [lakh] … divide it into tranches of 10 lakh each … all of it will become white … every year invest Rs. 10 [lakh] straightaway … you will not face any problem … and it will be tax-free … money [tax] will not get deducted …. and under the section [80C] you will also get [tax] rebate).”
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">
sans-serif; font-size: small;""><b>A. Mohan
column3: Deputy General Manager
column4: Central Bank of India
column5: Parliament Street
column6: New Delhi; G. Prakash
column7: Chief Manager
column8: LIC of India
column9: New Delhi

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small; text-indent: 0.5in;"">A. Mohan
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On getting us a very confidential account to help us invest our ill-gotten money:
sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;""> “Fir bhi main aapka ek aisi branch mein khulwa doonga jahan aap ghar ke paas ka account hoga aur bahut confidential rahega (Anyway
column3: I will get an account opened for you in a branch which is closer to your home and it will remain very confidential).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">                G. Prakash
sans-serif; font-size: small;"">Assuring us on secrecy:
sans-serif; font-size: small; text-indent: 0.5in;""> “Hum log bhi nahin batate kis ka paisa hai (We also don’t tell
column3: whose money it is).”

column2: sans-serif; font-size: small;"">On how even the taxman can’t dare ask the LIC anything about an invesetment:

sans-serif; font-size: small; margin-left: 0.5in;""> “LIC ... agar Income Tax Department bhi aate ... aise 23 crore policy bechi hui hain  .... kisika nahin dete ... unless ki attachment ho ... koi income [tax] authority mere paas aa ke nahin bol sakta hai ki inka policy number ye hai aur kitni paisa jama hai  (Even if the Income Tax Department comes ... 23 crore policies have been sold [by us] ... the LIC won’t tell about it to anybody ... unless there is an attachment ... none of the Income [Tax] authorities can come to us and giving us a policy number ask how much a fellow has deposited) ... They cannot ask.”
